Paxos offer is by far the best. The only one that can feasibly provide on/off-ramping capability via CEXes or regulated actors in a variety markets, including the EU. 

The HYPE community should value the easiness of bringing in new capital as this is key for growth. 

Paxos is the only one which will have guaranteed on/off-ramps. 

And on top of that they are an established player with robust processes, security, and regulatory setup.

My big question for everyone envisioning an ai driven economy / trading future is basically the gwart thread here

If agents are going to be so good at executing strategies and democratize finance what's stopping me from saying "hey claude, outperform blackrock by 25% today ty"

Signal to Noise is incredibly low as it is why add more bullshit noise for no reason

What you can do is just use the AI as a tool, give it a corpus of knowledge on protocols and various rates etc and ask questions of it.

you should be able to get answers to questions and suggest allotments, but ultimately execute the trade yourself.

I personally wouldn't trust an agent to do execution, unless it has been well battle tested by many others first.
steer clear of anyone who has an 'aI agent' that moves money for you. It's called quant trading and it's been done since 1980s and is highly recommended to not do with a shit LLM UX
Yeah, an AI agent who figured out the security part well is ideally the one to get 'funded'.

My reasoning for going towards Maker is that HL is high on community ownership and involvement and its community is very touchy now. Maker is one of the few teams which mostly had a patience and stamina to carry out the decentralised decision making for so long with very active participations and attracting a lot of intellect from outside the space. (like from TradFi)

So, alignment wise, Maker is the best.

My intent of asking this question is I want to know if there is any AI agent flexible enough in the market to do so. 

Also, if I had extra funds then I would foremost invest that into my project.
I don't see how anyone can beat the Paxos offering.

Is there an AI agent which can put in capital in equal value/weights across the entire list of Defillama yields when arranged from from top to bottom. 

The top yields are mainly LPs into pools and then later in stablecoin or vault yields coming up. So, 90% of the funds will be directed to LPs mainly. 

But is their an AI agent which can traverse across all these chains and put funds into all yield source mentioned there.

Ah okay, makes sense. Really good insights though! Iâ€™m not super at home in the VC world myself, but I can definitely imagine that with public markets being pretty strong and things like gold and Bitcoin pumping, thereâ€™s an argument for less exposure to VC (less liquid). I know at least that a lot of family offices have also scaled down on PE for this reason and started favouring public markets more again.
interesting! thanks for sharing

Mixed bag but a lot of it is downstream from the interest rate regime change. Granted some people played games thatâ€™d only work out in zirp times but the pain has been felt across the board. Even when you look outside of crypto a lot of the post-2019 vintages are underperforming

For those following the USDH discussions, Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts. Imo Sky, Ethena, Agora seem like the best options here. I'm not sure why Native Markets doesn't come up w something a bit more attractive. 

Note: I don't have more data that what I posted as a reference. https://x.com/lililashka/status/1965819845427016005

Do you think difficulty with closing new funds is due to past performance, or are other factors playing a role (macro, perhaps things like AI taking more of the forefront)? I know that doing a second fund is generally much harder than raising a first, but itâ€™s pretty interesting to hear that.
+ donâ€™t forget to ask your angels to do the legwork, so many teams barely ask for anything unless you chase

Not as much activity, high levels of concentration + the amounts raised are heavily disproportionate in the US (the valley) vs everywhere else. On top of that you have a large number of vcs that are struggling to close new funds (even t1s)
I think the key to raising is angels. You need some supporters in at a cheap price that are highly incentivised

Wouldnâ€™t you say that compared to previous cycles, raising funding has become harder? Perhaps Iâ€™m just in the wrong circles, but I definitely feel that many of the angels and VCs I speak with are much more selective this time around compared to 2021â€“2022. When you track the total amount raised per month, it also does seem like thereâ€™s less money flying around. Thereâ€™s still plenty though, with March seeing $3.55B raised in total, and June and August were also large months, but itâ€™s def not close to the craziness of 2021 raises (like 3 months of $3B+ raised and the top at $7B raised). I donâ€™t think going back to that level of craziness would even be a good thing tho, given where a lot of that funding ended up going.
Actual alpha today for once! / s

Without the above youâ€™re going to have a tough time competing.

Thanks for the insights. Yes Iâ€™ve been at the early stage for some time and found that angels and liquid V / f&f were amazing for that. 

Now weâ€™re at product stage we want to maintain the â€œanyone can get inâ€ framing but I imagine that at this stage to get meaningful money we will have to convince VCs to participate. 

Unless a certain policy decision makes people feel a bit looser in the near term.  Who knows

Hi there. 
I am building something on Hyperliquid. I heard in the kingdom chat that there is an HL group on TG. Can someone add me please?

I think frankly this stage is exceptional hard to raise unless you have good connections. It's a trust game. $10m is a shit load of money and why would they trust you more than the team who knows "jack" cus "jack" plays tennis with you and weekends and went to school with "dave" the founder of the other project

That's why being in SV helps so much. The trust aspect is the biggest hurdle for most VCs. I've heard stories of founders that raise a big round and just "rent an office by the beach", which they live in, and "buy a company car" which is a BMW and then do nothing - that scares the crap out of VCs because it's not even like they can sue them because of the risk-reward
Thereâ€™s so much PTSD in the space from extractive teams that when dedicated builders navigate funding they attract criticism from all sides. Classic crypto echo chamber things.

Great question â€” I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a single â€œcorrect path,â€ but there are definitely paths that undermine the ethos of decentralization and others that only pretend to serve it.

Projects face three funding phases (over simplifying here):

â€” Early (pre-product) â€” high risk, lots of uncertainty. ICOs have purity but are dangerous for retail (diligence burden, scams, compliance). Best path here is angels/VCs who can underwrite real risk.

â€” Mid-stage (post-MVP) â€” de-risked, tangible product. This is where raising from community makes the most sense, since people can actually evaluate the product. Unfortunately, most projects default to big VC rounds here â€” and this is when VC capital often turns predatory (short time to liquidity, misaligned incentives). Intuition is in this stage now, and weâ€™re leaning community-first, which I think is the healthier path. 

â€” Growth (post-token) â€” ideally transparent, with funding tied to DAO governance and community decisions.

Just used SheetHater for Token2049. Endorsed, it's great.

If anyone is heading to KBW and/or Token2049, @SheetHaterBot is live to apply for side events automatically based on the categories you choose. 

Some cool features: 
- Applies to 200 side events per conference
- Applies based on day/time in case you're arriving late or if you're a morning/night kinda person
- Tell it to apply for events by specific projects (or speakers) - just mention 'Monad' for example (see preferences section)
- Forward luma links from frens to the bot and it'll apply (if you set up your profile)
- Free to use
- Runs in a TEE (Marlin) so your info doesn't get shared with the devs.

For reviews, pls look at: https://x.com/SheetHater

Imo Kinto should resolve this Wildcat design flaw by repaying the lenders directly instead of depositing the 76% into the Wildcat contract. To avoid rugging some of their lenders completely.

TLDR: Kinto defaults on their loan due to their shutdown but will still repay 76% of the loan. However, due to Wildcat protocol design, lenders only have a 24h window (at some specific time in the future, not now) to queue their withdrawal tx, otherwise they'll receive 0 of this 76%.
